Evaluation of nanohydroxyapaptite (nano-HA) coated epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) cross-linked collagen membranes
Chenyu Chu a, Jia Deng a, Yi Man a,b,⁎, Yili Qu a,⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Oral Diseases, West China Hospital of Stomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610041, China b Department of Oral Implantology, West China Hospital of Stomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610041, China

Collagen is themain component of extracellularmatrix (ECM)with desirable biological activities and low antigenicity. Collagenmaterials have beenwidely utilized in guided bone regeneration (GBR) surgery due to its abilities to maintain space for hard tissue growth. However, pure collagen lacks optimal mechanical properties. In our previous study, epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) cross-linked collagenmembranes, with better biological activities and enhanced mechanical properties, may promote osteoblast proliferation, but their effect on osteoblast differentiation is not very significant. Nanohydroxyapatite (nano-HA) is the main component of mineral bone, which possesses exceptional bioactivity properties including good biocompatibility, high osteoconductivity and osteoinductivity, non-immunogenicity and non-inflammatory behavior. Herein, by analyzing the physical and chemical properties as well as the effects on promoting bone regeneration, we have attempted to present a novel EGCG-modified collagen membrane with nano-HA coating, and have found evidence that the novel collagenmembranemay promote bone regenerationwith a better surfacemorphology,without destroying collagen backbone. To evaluate the surface morphologies, chemical and mechanical properties of pure collagen membranes, epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) cross-linked collagen membranes, nano-HA coated collagen membranes, nano-HA coated EGCG-collagen membranes, (ii) to evaluate the bone regeneration promoted by theses membranes. In the present study, collagenmembraneswere divided into 4 groups: (1) untreated collagenmembranes (2) EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes (3) nano-HA modified collagen membranes (4) nano-HA modified EGCG-collagenmembranes. Scanning electronmicroscope (SEM) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) were used to evaluate surface morphologies and chemical properties, respectively. Mechanical propertieswere determinedbydifferential scanning calorimeter (DSC) and elasticmodulus (EM)measurements. Then in 12 rats, 4 types ofmembraneswere randomly applied to cover the rat calvarial defects. The animals were sacrificed at 8weeks. Histologic analyses were performed using Hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining andMasson's Trichrome stains. For statistical analysis, analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey's multiple comparison tests was applied. HA nanoparticles were fairly well distributed nanoparticles among the collagen fibers on the nano-HA-modified EGCG-collagen membranes, with smoother surface. Moreover, collagen membranes with modifications all maintained their collagen backbone and the mechanical properties were enhanced by EGCG and nano-HA treatments. In addition, EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes with nano-HA coatings promoted bone regeneration. Nano-HA modified EGCG-collagen membranes can be utilized as a barrier membrane to enhance the bone regeneration in GBR surgeries.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Guided bone regeneration (GBR) is often used in dental implant surgeries for bone augmentation. Collagen is themain component of extracellular matrix (ECM) with desirable biological activities and low antigenicity. Collagen materials have been widely utilized in GBR

surgery due to its abilities to maintain space for hard tissue growth and promote soft tissue regeneration as well [1–4]. However, pure collagen lacks optimal mechanical properties.
In the past decade, different methods have been applied to meet the demands of collagen membranes both in mechanical property and biocompatibility, and the mineralized collagen composite is one of the solutions [5–7]. Apart from the enhanced mechanical and biological properties, mineralized collagen also has a conductivity effect in promoting hard tissue growth. Recently, biomimetic mineralized collagen material, which is also called nanoapatite/collagen composite, have attracted much attention [8–12]. Nano-HA is the main component of
mineral bone, which has been widely used as a biocompatible ceramic for contact with bone tissue [13]. Due to its similarity with the hard tissues of the body, nano-HA possesses exceptional bioactivity properties including good biocompatibility, high osteoconductivity and osteoinductivity, non-immunogenicity and non-inflammatory behavior [14,15]. Moreover, it does not lead to local or systemic toxicity, or intervening fibrous tissues between implant and bone [16]. In

The beneficial roles of EGCG in dentistry include the reduction of oral cavity oxidative stress and inflammation in the presence of green tea polyphenols [19], association with Halitosis by suppressing themgl Gene [20] and involvement in inhibition of acid production in dental plaque bacteria [21]. In our previous study [22], after cross-linked by EGCG, collagen membranes are possessed with better biological activities and enhanced mechanical properties. While it is observed that EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes may promote osteoblast proliferation, the effect on osteoblast
differentiation is not very significant. Considering the desirable biological properties of nano-HA, it is interesting to knowwhether EGCG crosslinked collagen membranes with the nano-HA coatings have the effects on promoting osteoblast proliferation and differentiation.
The purpose of the present study was (i) to evaluate the surface morphologies, chemical and mechanical properties of nano-HA coated collagen membranes, EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes, nanoHA coated EGCG-collagen membranes, and control membranes, (ii) to evaluate bone regeneration promoted by theses membranes. The hypotheses were that i) nano-HA coated EGCG-collagen membranes possessed better surface morphologies, without destroying the collagen backbone (ii) nano-HA coated EGCG-collagen membranes can both significantly promote bone regeneration.

prepared with 10-mm diameter. EGCG was commercially available from Jiang Xi Lv Kang Natural Products (Jiang Xi, China). All solvents and chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification.
EGCG were dissolved in deionized water to prepare 0.64% (w/v) EGCG solutions. Collagen membranes were then immersed in 0.64% (w/v) EGCG solutions at 25 °C for 1 h. The resulted collagenmembranes were rinsed three times with deionized water and then freeze-dried overnight. A control group was incubated with deionized water under the same experimental conditions.
To fabricate the nano-HA-modified membranes and the nano-HAmodified EGCG-collagen membranes, the resulting samples were immersed in 100 mg/mL nano-HA solutions at 25 °C for 12 h, and then the samples were also freeze-dried overnight.

sections.heading: 2.2. Surface morphologies observation
sections.text: The surface morphologies of collagen membranes were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (S-800, HITACHI, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 25 kV. All samples were coated with an ultrathin layer (300 Å) of Au/Pt in an ion sputter (E1010, HITACHI, Tokyo, Japan) to achieve enough electrical conductivity.

sections.heading: 2.3. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis on chemical properties
sections.text: The chemical properties of collagen membranes were measured by an FTIR spectrophotometer (Spectrum One, PerkinElmer, Inc., Waltham) and the spectra were obtained at the average of 32 scans in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 at 25 °C.

sections.heading: 2.4. Mechanical properties
sections.text: Mechanical propertieswere determined by differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) and elastic modulus (EM) measurements. The samples were encapsulated in aluminum pans and heated from 25 to 500 °C at 10 °C/min under constant purging of nitrogen at 20 mL/min. Thermal denaturation was recorded as the typical peak. The elastic modulus (EM) of eachmembrane strained at a rate of 5mm/minwas determined using an Instron Series IX Automated Materials Testing System (Model 3342, Instron, Canton, MA, USA).

sections.heading: 2.5. In vivo test
sections.text: The protocol of the present experimentwas evaluated and approved by theAnimal Research Ethics Committee at the SichuanUniversity (No. WCHSIRB-D-2017-097). 12 adult male Sprague Dawley rats, weighing between 250 and 300 g were used. During the experiment, the animals were kept in a purpose-designed room for experimental animals and were fed a standard laboratory diet.

sections.heading: 2.6. Surgical procedures
sections.text: After full anaesthetization by chloral hydrate, the surgical area (the dorsal part of the cranium) was shaved and aseptically prepared. Then, a sagittal incision of approximately 20 mm was made over the scalp of the rats. After removing the periosteum, a full-thickness bone defect (5 mm in diameter) was made in the centre of each parietal bone by trephines using a slow speed dental drill. Heat damage on the rims of the host bone was prevented. Then, an untreated, EGCG crosslinked, nano-HA coated, or nano-HA coated EGCG cross-linked collagen membrane was covered randomly on bone defects (three rats of each group) and covered the areas fully. Incisions were sutured using horizontal mattress 3.0 Vicryl sutures. After recovering for 8 weeks postsurgery, animals were sacrificed by cervical dislocation. Samples of the membranes sites were harvested.

sections.heading: 2.7. Histologic analyses
sections.text: The obtained samples (each group of three samples) was placed in 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 24 h and decalcified in 15% EDTA for 3 weeks at 4 °C. After dehydration, the samples were embedded in paraffin and 3.5 mm longitudinal sections were used for proceeding. In addition, the sectionswere obtained by cutting through themidline or the central region of the circular defect. Histologic analyses (H&E and Masson's Trichrome stains respectively) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Moreover, CaseViewer were used to measure gapwidth, thickness of regenerated bone and number of complete closures.

sections.heading: 3.1. Surface morphologies
sections.text:
The surface morphologies of the treated and untreated collagen membranes were observed by SEM, shown in Fig. 1. Compare with pure collagen (Fig. 1A), EGCG cross-linked collage membranes (Fig. 1B) exhibited more ordered fiber aggregates and smoother surface. HA nanoparticles were present on both the nano-HA-modified collagen membranes (Fig. 1C) and the nano-HA-modified EGCG-collagen membranes (Fig. 1D). However, the nanoparticles were fairly well distributed nanoparticles among the collagen fibers on the nano-HA-modified EGCG-collagen membranes, while nanoparticles did not spread well and seemed to form aggregates on nano-HA-modified collagen membranes.

sections.heading: 3.2. FTIR analysis on chemical properties
sections.text:
FTIR spectra in Fig. 2 show the structural changes of collagen membranes. The amide I absorption at 1630 cm−1 is characteristic of carbonyl bond stretching in the protein linkage. The amide II bands at 1580 cm−1 corresponded to the coupling between N\\H bending vibrations and C\\N stretching vibrations. The amide III band in the 1235 cm−1 region was assigned to the C\\N stretching and N\\H bending vibration from amide linkages [23,24]. The amide I, II and III did not shift. In addition, the band ratios of the bands at 1235 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 are almost the same, indicating the maintenance of collagen backbone. Moreover, the peaks at the band at 1030 cm−1 only in nHA-Col and nHA-E-Col indicate the PO43− formation between nHA and collagen membranes.

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical properties
sections.text: Mechanical properties were determined by elasticity and thermal stability (Table 1). nHA-E-Col exhibited the highest EM, followed by ECol and then HA-Col, while Col showed the lowest EM as expected. However, E-Col presented the highest thermal stability, which is similar to that of HA-Col. Denaturation temperature (Td) of nHA-E-Col is slightly lower, but it is still higher than that of the pure collagen.

sections.heading: 3.4. Histologic analyses
sections.text:
After calvarial implantation, defect sites harvested 8weeks post-surgery to evaluate bone repair. As expected, nHA-E-Col exhibited the highest bone-healing efficacy. Clear defect bridging from the host bone and near closure by 8 weeks were obtained within the nHA-ECol defects (Fig. 3D). In addition, new bone was stimulated only minimally from the periphery of the defect in E-Col and HA-Col (Fig. 3B and C). Quantitative measurements (Fig. 4) further showed the highest bone-healing efficacy in nHA-E-Col, as the gap width was significantly lower than the other groups and the thickness of regenerated bone was significantly higher than those of nHA-Col and E-Col. None of the groups complete the closures.
Fibrous tissue could be seen within all groups (Fig. 5). Col showed the most collagen deposition. However, while E-Col and HA-Col groups showed amixture of newbone formationwithfibrous tissue, nHA-E-Col laid down a thick and ordered new bone formationwithout intervening of fibrous layer together with abundant blood vessels.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
The results of the present study demonstrated the potentials of nano-HA coated EGCG-collagenmembranes in GBR. The tested collagen membranes possess better surface morphologies, without destroying the collagen backbone, and the promotion on bone regeneration by nano-HA coated EGCG-collagen membranes.
The surface of HA coated EGCG-collagen membranes became compact, with fairly well distributed nanoparticles among the collagen fibers. HA nanoparticles were observed in nano-HA coated collagen membranes as well, but they did not spread well and seemed to form aggregates. This may due to the changes on surface morphologies by EGCG cross-linking. Our previous study showed that EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes possessed smoother surface with increased diameters of fibers, which also enhanced cell adhesion [22]. Therefore, EGCG modified collagen membranes may contribute to the surface distribution of HA nanoparticles after nano-HA coating.
The triple helix conformation is the crucial backbone to ensure biological properties of collagen. It is reported that EGCG is capable of maintaining collagen structural characteristics, resisting its degradation by collagenase. However, it is unknown whether nano-HAwould affect the collagen backbone. In the present study, the amide I, II, and III did not shift, and the band ratios of the bands at 1235 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 are almost the same, indicating that the triple helix conformation of collagen is not destroyed by the addition of EGCG or nano-HA, because amides I, II, and III represented an intact triple helix conformation [24]. Moreover, the peaks at the band at 1030 cm−1 only in nHACol and nHA-E-Col confirmed the PO43− formation between nHA and collagen membranes.
It is reported that collagen membranes must maintain their structure for a sufficient period of time to prevent epitheliummigration during early wound healing [25]. EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes possess enhanced mechanical properties [22]. In the present study, the elevated thermal stability and EM indicate the better mechanical properties of nHA-E-Col than those of pure collagen.
In our previous study [22], it is observed that EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes may promote osteoblast proliferation, but the effect on osteoblast differentiation is not very significant. Due to its similarity
with the hard tissues of the body, nano-HA possesses exceptional bioactivity properties including good biocompatibility, high osteoconductivity and osteoinductivity, non-immunogenicity and non-inflammatory behavior [14,15]. Therefore, histologic analyses were performed to evaluate the outcome of bone regeneration. The H&E analysis confirmed that HA modified EGCG-collagen membranes promoted bone healing by as early as 8 weeks. In addition, the outcome of bone regeneration of nHA-E-Col is better than that of E-Col, indicating the improvement of tissue regeneration by addition of HA coatings on EGCG cross-linked collagen membranes.
However, the results showed that nHA-Col group and E-Col group exhibited less bone regenerative ability than the Col group and the nHA-E-Col group. The higher concentration of EGCG may lead to inhibitory effect, as shown in our previous study [22]. Moreover, the immune response based on the implantation of collagen membranes also plays an important role in GBR [26]. It is reported that macrophages spread well with increasing surface roughness [27], which may result in promotion on inflammatory effects. Nano-HA modified collagen membranes possessed a relatively rougher surface, indicated by the aggregations of nano-HA on the surface of nano-HA modified collagen membranes (Fig. 1C). Therefore, nano-HA modified collagen membranes may induce an increase in inflammatory factors, which is subsequently not beneficial for bone regeneration [28]. However, EGCG crosslinked collagenmembranes can reduce the level of inflammatory factors [22].Moreover, nano-HA spread evenly on the surface of nano-HAmodified EGCG-collagen membranes. Altogether, the results showed that nano-HAmodified EGCG-collagen membranes is beneficial for bone regeneration as expected. Further studies are still needed to determine an appropriate concentration of EGCG and promote bone regeneration depended on the modulation of immune response.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The present study demonstrated that the HA modified EGCG-collagenmembranes promote bone regeneration. In addition, with themodification of HA nanoparticles, the nano-HA spread evenly over the surface of EGCG-collagenmembranes.Moreover, the nano-HAmodified EGCG-collagen membranes possessed better mechanical properties, without destroying the collagen backbone. Consequently, the nano-HA modified EGCG-collagen membranes demonstrated its ability to serve as a barrier membrane with the option of enhancing the bone regeneration in GBR surgeries.
